newsitem.title: FRANCE: France's Chirac takes mid-campaign Cannes detour.
newsitem.headline: France's Chirac takes mid-campaign Cannes detour.

text.p: French President Jacques Chirac, enmeshed in a snap parliamentary election campaign, took a trip to the Cannes film festival on Sunday for a high-profile luncheon surrounded by glamorous cinema stars.

French presidents generally try to remain above politics during campaigns, but that did not prevent Chirac from presiding over a glittery luncheon at the Cannes Palais des Festivals, where he sat between actresses Isabelle Adjani of France and Gong Li of China.
Chirac, the first sitting president to visit Cannes during the annual film festival, was soon seen on television newscasts chatting and laughing with the two stars.
Both women are on the Cannes jury which hands out the festival awards including the coveted Golden Palm, and Adjani is its president.
Also attending the luncheon were a number of past Cannes Golden Palm winners including Michelangelo Antonioni, Francis Ford Coppola and Shohei Immamura.

"I am happy to be here to pay my respects to the great personalities of the seventh art, but I am especially pleased to pay homage to the French cinema, which is vibrant, growing and successful," Chirac said in brief remarks.
"Our film industry is an important asset to our culture, our influence and our economy," he said.

The festival is feting its 50th birthday this year, with a star-studded gala on Sunday night. But Chirac returned to Paris after just three hours in the Riviera resort town, despite widespread rumours he would change his plans and stay.

Chirac stunned the French political world last month by dissolving parliament nine months ahead of schedule and setting a snap parliamentary election for May 25-June 1 though his centre-right government enjoyed an overwhelming majority in the National Assembly.
He said he wanted a renewed assembly with a five-year mandate for reform.
But his political gamble is up in the air as polls portray a tight contest, with the left within striking distance of ousting the centre-right from power.
French presidents typically stay off the campaign trail. But Cannes was his second high-profile weekend public appearance.
On Saturday evening, he attended the French soccer cup final at Paris' Parc des Princes stadium.
